A monoid involving a set MMM requires some multiplication function μ:M×M→M\mu: M \times M \to Mμ:M×M→M. Noticing this, we can be inspired to define a monoid internal to any category with products. Our multiplication for a monoid involving an object MMM will be a morphism μ:M×M→M\mu: M \times M \to Mμ:M×M→M. However, we can generalize further and define a monoid in any monoidal category! Then the "multiplication" for a monoid involving an object MMM in a monoidal category CCC involves a morphism μ:M⊗M→M\mu: M \otimes M \to Mμ:M⊗M→M. Here ⊗:C×C→C\otimes: C \times C \to C⊗:C×C→C is the functor that is part of the data that makes CCC a monoidal category.

So, although our initial definition of a monoid involved a morphism from a product, it turns out we can define monoids internal to monoidal categories. And we don't need to use a product in the process! Instead, we can do this by making use of the "product-like" functor ⊗\otimes⊗ any monoidal category provides.

I am wondering if a similar thing can be done for categories instead of monoids. Now, in a category we can't compose all our morphisms: we can only compose a morphism bbb after a morphism aaa if the target of aaa is the source of bbb. To express this fact, one can form the pullback C1×C0C1C_1 \times_{C_0} C_1C1​×C0​​C1​, which is the limit of the diagram C1→tC0←sC1C_1 \to_t C_0 \leftarrow_s C_1C1​→t​C0​←s​C1​. Here C1C_1C1​ is our collection of arrows and C0C_0C0​ is our collection of objects, while s:C1→C0s:C_1 \to C_0s:C1​→C0​ tells us the source of any given arrow, and t:C1→C0t:C_1 \to C_0t:C1​→C0​ tells us the target of any given arrow. Assuming we have a set of objects and a set of arrows, C1×C0C1C_1 \times_{C_0} C_1C1​×C0​​C1​ is then the set containing pairs of arrows (a,a′)(a,a')(a,a′) such that t(a)=s(a′)t(a)=s(a')t(a)=s(a′). Each element of this set corresponds to a pair of composable arrows. Our composition of arrows can then be defined by a function c:C1×C0C1→C1c:C_1 \times_{C_0} C_1 \to C_1c:C1​×C0​​C1​→C1​ which sends each pair of composable arrows to its composite.

To define a category internal to some other category DDD, we then ask for (among other things) some objects C1C_1C1​ and C0C_0C0​, and some morphisms s:C1→C0s:C_1 \to C_0s:C1​→C0​ and t:C1→C0t:C_1 \to C_0t:C1​→C0​. If DDD has pullbacks, then we can form C1×C0C1C_1 \times_{C_0} C_1C1​×C0​​C1​ as the limit (pullback) of the diagram C1→tC0←sC1C_1 \to_t C_0 \leftarrow_s C_1C1​→t​C0​←s​C1​. And then we can define a "composition" morphism c:C1×C0C1→C1c:C_1 \times_{C_0} C_1 \to C_1c:C1​×C0​​C1​→C1​, and we are on our way to specifying some category internal to DDD.

I am curious if we can do all this without requiring the pullback of C1→tC0←sC1C_1 \to_t C_0 \leftarrow_s C_1C1​→t​C0​←s​C1​ to exist in DDD. Instead, perhaps we could make use of a "pullback-like" functor P:DJ→DP:D^J \to DP:DJ→D, where JJJ is the category that looks like this (omitting identity arrows): 0→1←0′0 \to 1 \leftarrow 0'0→1←0′. So DJD^JDJ is the category of functors from JJJ to DDD, which is the category of diagrams of shape JJJ in DDD. If DDD actually has pullbacks, then PPP can really be the functor that sends each diagram in DDD of shape JJJ to its pullback. And then we can define the source and target of our composition morphism as c:P(C1→tC0←sC1)→C1c:P(C_1 \to_t C_0 \leftarrow_s C_1) \to C_1c:P(C1​→t​C0​←s​C1​)→C1​.

But if DDD doesn't have pullbacks, maybe sometimes we can still define a (generalized "category internal to DDD". I'm hoping that a functor P:DJ→DP:D^J \to DP:DJ→D that is "pullback-like" can be used instead, so that we can then define an category internal to DDD using some composition morphism c:P(C1→tC0←sC1)→C1c:P(C_1 \to_t C_0 \leftarrow_s C_1) \to C_1c:P(C1​→t​C0​←s​C1​)→C1​.

I am wondering these things:

  • Can we get a structure that could be reasonably called a (generalized) "category internal to DDD" using some functor PPP that isn't a "take the pullback" functor?
  • What would PPP need to be like, to achieve this?
  • Could we maybe do a similar thing with other limits or colimits? For example, we might want to have "equalizers" in a category that doesn't really have equalizers, but supports an "equalizer-like" functor to it. This functor should then, at least in some important ways, act like the functor that takes limits of diagrams of the appropriate shape.

Any thoughts are welcome!

You can make a category with finite products into a monoidal category by letting the product be the monoidal product. Similarly, you can make a category with finite coproducts into a monoidal category by letting the coproduct be the monoidal product. (See here, for example.)

In general though, the monoidal product doesn't need to be the product or coproduct in the category we are working in. (Although I wouldn't say that it is an "arbitrary operation").

I find the concept of a monoid in a monoidal category exciting. That's because of this: you can get many interesting structures just by considering monoids in different monoidal categories! Here are a few structures you can form by considering monoids in appropriate monoidal categories:

  • monoids
  • commutative monoids
  • rings
  • algebras
  • monads
  • unital quantales

These examples were taken from this list.

If you have some monoidal category of interest, you can arrive at a potentially interesting notion just by considering what a monoid would look like in that category! (I call this sort of thing an "idea machine".)
